ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would definitely recommend the course - its a great introduction to the faculty and their work.

I would recommend this class for all incoming American Studies students if it were not already a requirement. It creates cohesion among the cohort and is an excellent way to become acquainted with many of the department's faculty members and their work.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I felt I knew the faculty well after the course but not the profession so much. It would have been nice to have a bit more of an introduction to American Studies- a history of the field, necessary readings, etc.

I respect the hesitancy to define a canon of disciplinary texts central to American Studies as a field. Nevertheless, there are trends at play in our interdisciplinary discipline and I think it would be helpful to incorporate more interdisciplinary discipline training/reading in the course. I am thinking here of key eras (myth and symbol) and publications (Cultures of US Imperialism). While we can argue against any one text being considered canonical at the expense of another, it is unreasonable to deny that there is a terrain to the field of American Studies that has been marked by certain authors, concepts, and publications.I am looking forward to Matt Jacobson's US Cultural Historiography course next term; its structure, assignments, and the skill set (e.g., reading practices especially) it develops seem vital to graduate level success in American Studies.
